description.narrative:
In Sudan, this Reconstruction programme will focus on the following outcomes:
Outcome 1: Increased trust and cooperation among and within the various groups
Outcome 2: Reduction of land and water issues
Outcome 3: Increased utilization of alternative livelihood resources and formal & non-formal education systems
Number of direct and indirect beneficiaries approximately 20.000 – 30.000.

The proposed programme will contribute to the improvement of human safety by focusing on land and water issues, through a comprehensive and appropriate package of interventions in three areas facing similar issues. These areas are selected districts of northern Afghanistan; Dar El Salaam and Kalamendo localities in North Darfur, Sudan; and Amudat District in the Karamoja region of north-eastern Uganda.

participating-org.narrative: The North Darfur Voluntary Network for Rural Development (“the Network”)

activity-date.narrative: The project received initial approval from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs on 28th June 2012 for a total amount of 60% of the proposed budget at the time of submission in March 2012. ZOA was then asked to submit a revised project plan by latest 15th September 2012. The Ministry notified ZOA of the approval of the revised plan on 16th November 2012, after which ZOA started implementation of the project. ZOA found it best to not start the revised project immediately after submission in September 2012 so not to run the risk of beginning project work on a wrong footing, we considered the operational risks of starting the project without having received the donor’s ultimate directions, too high. Therefore, we could only start full project preparations in second half of November.

description.narrative: Incoming fund from RECON1 programme, August 2013
Incoming fund from RECON1 programme, December 2013
Incoming fund from RECON1 programme, February 2013
Incoming fund from RECON1 programme, February 2015
Incoming fund from RECON1 programme, June 2014

transaction.ref: Total Expenditures under this activity until end of project

description.narrative: Access to alternative livelihood opportunities is increased
By the end of the project, 100 households in Sudan have added at least one new livelihoods strategy to their portfolio

comment.narrative: N/A
Five SBG groups comprising 24 HHs from 5 different communities formed and trained. Their proposals are already submitted for starting their new businesses. The proposals are assessed and approved.

So far, 23 grants have been disbursed, benefiting about 115 households. The plan is to approve 45 grants, which will benefit about 200 households. There are however concerns about profitability and long-term viability of some of the smaller grants.

The modality of giving the small grants to the PTAs (6 grants) proved the high efficiency & effectiveness of the grant. At least 25% of the SG beneficiaries acquired more than one strategy to make their business successful. Good example of that was that they began to adopt a strategy of changing the type of the business according to the markets' needs & the seasonality of the inputs needed or the business, such as food technologies & petty trade.

description.narrative: By the end of the project, 40% of new small enterprises established under this project are functional and profitable.

comment.narrative: N/A

During November 2015, the FSL Advisor and the M&E conducted a evaluation of the small business grants and found that 65% of these businesses operate with good revenue that enabled these households to improve their livelihoods; some maintained their buildings, other secured their children's education and part of them extended their businesses to secure more revenue.
Five SBG groups comprising 24 HHs from 5 different communities formed and trained. Their proposals are already submitted for starting their new businesses. The proposals are assessed and approved.

The small business grants distributed during 2014 (5 grants) & 2015 (35 grants) & since such activity need some good time to produce results; the early monitoring showed only about 65% of the grants are functional and profitable.
Too early to tell, but there are some concerns about the financial sustainability of part of the enterprises (see above) SBGs assessment is planned in 2015

description.narrative: Access to water is increased
By the end of the project, year round safe drinking water availability per capita has increased by 15% in at least 50% of the targeted communities in Afghanistan and Sudan.

comment.narrative: N/A
15%: increase (when compared to baseline) in water availability per capita 50%: of the targeted communities
11,4% increase for 5,547 HHs A mini-water survey within 4 target communities is to be conducted in February 2014. The number of HHs accessing water all year around is 5,547.
15%: increase (when compared to baseline) in water availability per capita 50%: of the targeted communities
2 water points rehabilitated, ZOA rehabilitated one fully and contributed with the community for rehabilitation of other.
15%: increase (when compared to baseline) in water availability per capita 50%: of the targeted communities
Around 61% of the total target group who have an increased availability of water of 75% (from 12 to 21 liter per person)
15%: increase (when compared to baseline) in water availability per capita 50%: of the targeted communities

The project’s water interventions have contributed to an increase in year round safe drinking water availability, but much of this improvement was undone by the loss of the Sag el Naam water yards, which dramatically increased pressure on water points in Goz Beina, Shawa, and Abu Delek clusters. With the water interventions planned in the remainder of the project (especially the new water point in Gedeil Wagif, Goz Beina cluster), the situation should improve substantially.

description.narrative: Availability of formal education facilities and non-formal education has increased
By the end of the project, 30% of the targeted communities in Uganda and Sudan have access to an adequate primary education facility within 5 km walking distance

comment.narrative: N/A

According to the latest survey (February 2014), about 50% of the targeted communities has an adequate school within 5 km walking distance. This survey covers 7 schools and 35 villages (Shawa and Sag el Naam are not included). As the target has been reached, some funds have been shifted to output 3.2.
Approximately 50% of targeted communities have access to adequate primary education within 5km (Result in 2014)

Based on reports of the project education officer & checklist answered by PTAs through FGDs it is found that 50% of the HHs located outside the 5 km range have their children in education according to ZOA /BUZA support. FGDs were conducted in December 2013.
The accessibility of basic schooling students measured twice a year due to the nature of the seasonality of the area.

description.narrative: Capacity for increased productivity of crops and/or livestock is improved
At the end of the project, at least 60% of targeted households are independently sourcing and correctly using at least one of the new agricultural inputs introduced through the project

comment.narrative: Baseline: Fertilizer use: 0% Herbicide use: 0% Rainwater harvesting: 0%

288 farmers (173 male and 115 female) received training about improved seeds, terracing and integrative pest management. These farmers have all adopted the new techniques. 60 farmer households (40 male and 20 female farmers) received a donkey plough and instructions not only how to use them but also to train 5 other farmers each as these ploughs are meant to be community property. 12 farmers received training regarding fertilizer (pilot project with demonstration farms).
4 seedbanks constructed. 1600 HHs (approximately 8000 people) received improved seeds.

In total, 2,000 households received seeds so far, and the donkey ploughs distributed under this project are used by about 380-400 households. Fertiliser trials benefitted 72 households. Assuming that about half of the farmers who use the donkey ploughs also benefited from the seed distribution, this means that in total about 2,200 households, or over 60% of the total number of households in the project area, are using at least one new agricultural input. On top of this, there are indications that households in the southern clusters have shared some of the improved seeds that they received with other households, both within and outside the targeted village clusters. When it comes to independent sourcing of inputs, people can access the donkey ploughs through the agricultural committees, and they may be able to save some of the improved seeds. It is not clear if many people will be able to purchase donkey ploughs and improved seeds by themselves. The trainings on pest management ad seed storage were give through FFS in December, the results will only be clear in 2015/2016.

No own demonstration yet of HH investments. Fertillizer demonstrations were done with 100 farming HHs during the last rainy farming season (July 2013 - January 2014). The 100 farming HHs acquired the knowledge and usefullness of using fertilizers.

description.narrative: Capacity of grassroots mitigation and prevention mechanisms is enhanced
By the end of the project 75% of the people in each community can identify and have confidence in the relevant grassroots bodies

comment.narrative: N/A

97% of the people of the communities can identify grassroots bodies. The project succeeded in facilitating the development of community based conflict mitigation mechanisms and encouraged the culture of negotiations between different community groups through capacity building and formation of the FDGs.

In each project's target community, two FGDs were established by the community itself, one constant & formed from selected women & men, where the second one is changeable ; one turn of women and the next turn of men (these groups include youth as well). Each FGD meets quarterly to assess the community cooperation, harmony & cohesion and also to investigate the disagreements that resolved locally & those addressed externally. During 2016 well noted that the FGDs operate efficiently.
Indications from the evaluation and data from FGDs show that this indicator is on the way to being achieved.
No data reported

description.narrative: By the end of the project, 75% of the targeted members of grassroots bodies can explain how they will use what they learnt about mitigation and prevention in practice

comment.narrative: N/A
During the FGD held in april 2016 100% of the people can explain how they used what they had learned bout conflict mitigation and prevention in practice.
No data reported
Too early to tell. Traditional leaders have only just been trained.

this percentage is close to 100%. During two Focus Group Discussions held in 2015, 97% of randomly chosen people from the communities were already able to accurately describe what these committees' main purpose is. This and the fact that a significant percentage of disagreements were resolved peacefully, are proxy indicators that the committees are doing a good job

description.narrative: Capacity of local leadership and civil society to manage land and water resources in a sustainable, effective, equitable way is enhanced
At least 80% of agreed capacity strengthening measures with partner organisations have been implemented by the partner.

comment.narrative: N/A
N/A
Not implemented yet. Partner assessed (C5) and capacity building plan produced and agreed among partner organisation and ZOA.

Not reported, but same as under output indicator 1.2.3: For 2014, three capacity strengthening measures were agreed with VNRHD: strengthening the ‘strategic dimensions’ of VNRHD and the internal and external communication about this; professionalising VNRHD’s administration; and developing and implementing an appropriate M&E system. A strategic planning workshop was conducted for VNRHD, which led to the development of a strategic plan for 2014-2016. Two training workshops , on HR and finance, were held in November and December 2014.

The VNW which trained by the project as implementing partner; conducted more than 6 training sessions for the project community leaders on grassroots conflict mitigation techniques. This proves the sustainability of the action.

description.narrative: By the end of the project, 60% of water management committees are able to demonstrate learned skills and knowledge

comment.narrative: N/A
12 committees were trained, of which 4 have been assessed. All four (100%) were able to demonstrate learned skills and knowledge.

4 Out of 12 water committees in the project target area assessed and trained on (a) Community Awareness Raising on importance of Environmental Sanitation, (b) Management Skills, (c) Cleaning the water point and equipment, and (d) Organizing the work and water distribution.
Surveys in 2015 show that this is still 100%

WMCs practiced the acquired skills & knowledge in maintaining & managing the water sources at their communities. For example in 2016 Abudelek WMC showed very effective management in managing the water sources (Abudelek borehole & Abudelek water yard; where there is a pressure of water users insiders & outsiders.

description.narrative: Capacity of relevant NGOs and governmentt bodies to support grassroots mitigation and prevention mechanisms is enhanced
At least 80% of agreed capacity strengthening measures with partner organisations have been implemented.

comment.narrative: N/A
All allocated capacity building for VNW carried out in 2014 & 2015

All capacity building that was agreed upon between ZOA and the partners, was carried out (training in peace building and various aspects of Project Cycle Management). In other words - what ZOA promised, it did. The result, ie the extent to which the acquired skills have been implemented cannot be measured in percentages. ZOA notices that partners are more skilled in helping communities solve conflicts peacefully. ZOA also notices that for example reporting from the partners has improved

For 2014, three capacity strengthening measures were agreed with VNRHD: strengthening the ‘strategic dimensions’ of VNRHD and the internal and external communication about this; professionalising VNRHD’s administration; and developing and implementing an appropriate M&E system. A strategic planning workshop was conducted for VNRHD, which led to the development of a strategic plan for 2014-2016. Two training workshops , on HR and finance, were held in November and December 2014.
Not reported

description.narrative: By the end of the project, 60% of grassroots mitigation / prevention bodies (mainly Shuras, Judiyahs and other grassroots bodies) in the targeted areas can give concrete examples of coaching by local government and local civil society

comment.narrative: N/A

10 Focus Discusion Groups at grass-root formed and trained to assess and mitigate local issues. Total of 97 persons (male and female) are member of these FDGs. Two assessments were carried out by the FDGs during 2013 (each 6 months). 58 cases of disagreements have been reported with 50 of them addressed locally. The level of harmony and cohesion was assessed at 56%

Same as under output indicator 1.2.1: Too early to tell. Capacity building of NGO staff on mitigation and prevention was done in Q4. Government staff was not trained, but traditional leaders were included.
The only monitoring mechanism that was used by the communities themselves were the FGDs. The FGDs presented good skills to address grassroots conflicts.

description.narrative: By the end of the project, 60% of trained government and/or NGO staff can give clear examples of how they can use the skills they learnt to coach.

comment.narrative: N/A
During 2016, the trained conflict prevention bodies addressed most of the disagreements (more than 60%) in their communities and resolved them locally & peacefully.
Not reported; Arrangements for organizing the training are going on.

The Voluntary Network for Rural Helping and Development has been trained in topics such as monitoring and evaluation, proposal writing, reporting as well as finance management. They in turn assist the CBOs in the project areas. Staff from the Ministry of Agriculture received training in soil testing and analysis. This is very helpful because regularly wrong sites for water drilling have been selected, which is a waste of resources.
Too early to tell. Capacity building of NGO staff on mitigation and prevention was done in Q4. Government staff was not trained, but traditional leaders were included.

description.narrative: Capacity of relevant organisations and institutions to manage education facilities and support alternative livelihoods options is enhanced
By the end of the project, 50% of the non-teacher members of PTAs have one or more children in the school, with gender and tribal affiliation incorporated in the measurement

comment.narrative: 16% of PTA members are female (other aspects of this indicator were not asked during baseline)
According to a survey in February 2014 (conducted in only four schools), 73% of PTA members, non-teachers, had one or more children in school.

All the project PTAs reviewed & monitored to figure out the percentage of PTAs who have one or more children in the school. The result showed that about 73% of the PTAs have one or more children in the school.
Eight out of 11 PTA members that were monitored had at least one child in school (73%) (Result in 2014)

In four clusters the indicator was assessed and out of 56 non-teacher PTA members (8 females) 41% had children in the schools. Main reason is the high number of orphans. Division between boys and girls is (generally over the schools) 53% boys and 47% girls. Per school no difference in tribal affiliation is recorded, however between schools the tribel affiliations differ.

description.narrative: By the end of the project, 60% of PTA/SMC members are able to give relevant examples of how they are involved in the monitoring of the school

comment.narrative: N/A

56 PTA members (48 male & 8 female) from 4 villages (Faki Ali, Gos Beina, Hay Aljame and Ed Albeida) in project target communities established and supported by management training, in order to support their schools and to be capable to monitor the education processes at their schools. Some members assist in all type of practical work as well (example: arranging water). 23 out of 56 members (= 41%) could give examples of being involved

73% of the interviewed people from the Parent Teacher Associations (PTAs) are able to give examples of their involvement in the monitoring of the schools. Any support to the schools via the PTAs is much appreciated because there is no assistance at all from any other organisation.

The February 2014 survey indicated that a little over 40% of interviewed PTA/SMC members are able to give relevant examples of how they are involved in the monitoring of the school. This will need some more follow-up attention.

Within the same assessment of figuring out the percentage of PTAs who have one or more children in the school, assessment of the capability fo the PTAs to monitoring their schools was conducted. Again 73% of them have improved their skills & capability to monitor their school's performance.

description.narrative: Increased trust and cooperation among and within the various groups

By the end of the project, 40% of people in the targeted areas in Afghanistan and Sudan can give examples of increased/renewed cooperation between stakeholder groups that positively affects their own lives

comment.narrative: N/A
From the last FGD conducted in April 2016 100% of people can provide an example of increased cooperation
No data reported on outcome level yet

The only data available are records of Focus Group Discussions, of which two are held twice a year in each cluster. While FGD records (and observations during the evaluation) indicate that much more than 40% of the participants can give examples of increased / renewed cooperation between stakeholder groups. The relatively limited number of FGD participants means that no robust statistical analysis of the data can be done.

Through Focus Group Discussions 100% of the people were able to give examples of increased cooperation. These FGDs have been conducted regularly, the last ones in October 2015. At the time of the start of this project an estimated 95% of the conflicts over land and/or water could not be resolved in a peaceful manner

description.narrative: Increased utilization of alternative livelihood resources and formal & non-formal education systems
By the end of the project, at least 100 households in the targeted areas in Sudan have increased their income through alternative sources

comment.narrative: N/A
115 households have received grants, but it is too early to tell whether there has been a real increase of income.
No data reported on outcome level yet
Results is 120-200: A total of 40 grants distributed that supported more than 100 HHs because each grant distributed to a group of 3-5 HHs.
The total number of households during the course of this project is 210 (115 in 2014 and 95 in 2015). 65% of these households have an increase in income, which is 136 households

description.narrative: By the end of the project, primary school attendance in target areas in Uganda and Sudan has increased by 25%

comment.narrative: Total number of students as at Jul-12 (adjusted for closure of some schools in late 2012).
an increase of 25% when compared to the baseline (2.179)

Enrolment, not attendance has been monitored. Several people mentioned substantial increases in school enrolment (including children shifting from schools in Zamzam and El Fasher to the schools in their village, as well as a larger percentage of children newly joining the school). Unfortunately, enrolment data for 2012/3, 2013/4 and 2014/5 only show an increase in enrolment in two schools out of seven.
an increase of 25% when compared to the baseline (2.179)
In 2014 the enrollment in the target are was 3015 and in 2015 it was 3575. This is an increase of 18.6%. The increase compared to the baseline (2,179 students) is 64%
an increase of 25% when compared to the baseline (2.179)
No data reported on outcome level yet
an increase of 25% when compared to the baseline (2.179)
The target was achieved and more awareness was created on the importance of basic education in the project target area.

description.narrative:
No progress yet on outcome/output level as in description due to a revision of the project plan by latest 15th September 2012. The Ministry notified ZOA of the approval of the revised plan on 16th November 2012, after which ZOA started implementation of the project. Therefore below some general information on implementation per country:
SUDAN: In Sudan the work during the reporting period focused on preparation and planning of agricultural and water activities for the project. No actual project implementation has taken place in the project area in North Darfur. Based on primary research done earlier in the year, ZOA spent this period developing a detailed strategy for agricultural interventions, including consultation with the Ministry of Agriculture and other stakeholders. This planning has placed ZOA Sudan in a strong position to implement agricultural activities in time for the 2013 agricultural season. ZOA also finalized its detailed water needs assessment, undertook geophysical survey of prospective water point locations and began technical preparations for water interventions.

title.narrative: Not applicable for this annual report: see narrative above

description.narrative: Reduction of land and water issues
By the end of the project, 50% of the targeted agricultural households have increased their annual cereal crop production by at least 10%

comment.narrative: Average household crop production (in kg)
an increase of 10% when compared to the baseline (498 kg)

In 2014 there is an increase in the food production by 4%; so the total increase so far is 13.5%. A mini household survey was used to collect information on production in 2012/3 and 2013/4. Data for the 2014/15 cultivation season are not available yet. When comparing households who received seed support with households who did not receive seed support, there is a substantial increase in sorghum yield It is likely that the target will be met. Donkey ploughs have helped people to double their acreage, and the terraces are enabling households to access fertile land. However, it must be noted that rainfall in 2014 was better than average, so any surveys in subsequent years may generate lower average yields/harvests.
an increase of 10% when compared to the baseline (498 kg)
No data reported on outcome level yet
an increase of 10% when compared to the baseline (498 kg)

The project was aiming at a sustainable increase of harvest which would ensure food security for the target beneficiaries. The project succeeded in enabling the target farmers to acquired the farming skills, knowledge and techniques that would have led to better harvest / production IF other natural factors were good. However during the farming season 2015 the rains were very poor in North Darfur and that affected the harvest very severely (the situation has been considered as a natural disaster). All farmers indicated that the 2015 harvest was a lot lower than that of the previous year. (target achieved in 2014 but negative result in 2015)
an increase of 10% when compared to the baseline (498 kg)

The target was achieved by the end of 2014 but in 2015 the harvest was very poor because of lack of rain (thus a factor beyond the control of ZOA) . Less than 50% of the target farmers were keeping improved seeds for next season (2016), in addition to the fact that all project's target farmers acquired farming knowledge that gained from the project and that will support food production in the future.

description.narrative: By the end of the project, there is an increase of 20% in resolved issues that people have experienced themselves

comment.narrative: Baseline data not available until end-July 2013.
An increase of 20% but no specific target, because no baseline
According to the last FGD conducted in April 2016, 82% of the conflict that people experienced themselves were resolved peacefully.
An increase of 20% when compared to the baseline, but baseline data not available until end-July 2013
No data reported on outcome level yet
An increase of 20% when compared to the baseline, but baseline data not available until end-July 2013

Same as under outcome 1: The only data available are records of Focus Group Discussions, of which two are held twice a year in each cluster. HH questionnaires on conflict are not allowed. While FGD records (and observations during the evaluation) indicate that much more than 40% of the participants can give examples of increased / renewed cooperation between stakeholder groups. The relatively limited number of FGD participants means that no robust statistical analysis of the data can be done.
An increase of 20% but no specific target, because no baseline

Two extensive sets of Focus Group Discussions were conducted in 2015, one in early August and the other one at the end of October. During both surveys 10 focus groups were interviewed. Over 95% of the members were able to accurately describe what the main responsibilities are of grassroot committees dealing with conflict resolution. Moreover both surveys showed that the majority of the identified disagreements in the communities, were resolved peacefully (In August 20 of the 23 and in October 26 of the 33 disagreements - 87% resp. 79%). These percentages were even higher (>90%) when the interviewees were reporting on disagreements they themselves were involved in.
